response.feedback: Correct. Histamine released from intracellular granules is part of the inflammatory and allergic pathways.
Incorrect. Histamine is released by mast cells or basophiles, not directly by damaged tissue cells.
Incorrect. Histamine does not freely circulate in the serum and is not a protein.
Incorrect. Histamine is locally released from the granules of mast cells and basophils.
Incorrect. Histamine is released from mast cells it does not interact with iron.
Incorrect. Histamine has some similar functions but probably does not play a role in pathogen adherence during phagocytosis.
Incorrect. Kinins are normally found in their inactive form circulating in the blood.
Incorrect. Kinins are found as freely circulating proteins and not contained within mast cell granules.
Incorrect. Kinins are plasma-derived signaling molecules that are vasoactive but do not promote phagocytosis.
Correct. Kinins are are groups of signaling molecules that can stimulate several different responses.
Incorrect. Kinins are signaling molecules that circulate in the blood; they do not interact with iron molecules.
Incorrect. Kinins are circulating molecules and not derived from mast cells and basophils.
Correct. Prostaglandins release is part of the the bodies response to tissue damage and they work with other chemicals to mediate inflammation.
Incorrect. Prostaglandins are lipid derived molecules released by local tissue cells during tissue damage.
Incorrect. Prostaglandins are lipids and not proteins.
Incorrect. Although prostaglandins can contribute to these effects, prostaglandins are not plasma derived.
Incorrect. Prostaglandins are lipids and not proteins.
Incorrect. Prostaglandins are not a major chemical released from mast cells or basophils.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes are signaling molecules that are more commonly generated in response to an allergic reaction, not direct tissue damage.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes are signaling molecules and are not released by mast cells or basophils.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes are eicosanoids (lipids) and not proteins.
Incorrect. Although leukotrienes can produce many similar effects, they are produced by mast cells and are not plasma derived.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes are eicosanoids not proteins.
Correct. Leukotrienes are signaling molecules that contribute to a variety of functions
Incorrect. Complement proteins are found in their inactive form circulating in the blood.
Incorrect. Complement is found circulating in the blood and is not released by mast cells or basophils.
Correct. These proteins circulate in the blood and are important for opsonization of infections agents, histamine release and the formation of a membrane attack complex.
Incorrect. Complement can stimulate histamine release and contribute to opsonization, but it doesnâ€™t directly stimulate these effects.
Incorrect. Complement proteins do not transport iron.
Incorrect. Complement is found freely circulating and is not released in direct response to cell signaling.
Incorrect. Transferrins are plasma proteins that bind and transport iron.
Incorrect. Transferrins are found circulating in the blood, they are not released from mast cells or basophils.
Incorrect. Transferrins are transport proteins specialized for carrying iron. They do not have enzymatic function.
Incorrect. Transferrins are proteins the transport iron throughout the body.
Correct. Transferrins bind iron so they can transport it. If the iron is bound to transferrin it is not available for use by bacteria.
Incorrect. Transferrins are plasma proteins that carry iron.
